verb.description: Notice or perceive (something) and register it as being significant.
examples: young people observe that decisions are made by others
a stockbroker once observed that dealers live and work in hell

verb.description: Fulfill or comply with (a social, legal, ethical, or religious obligation)
examples: a tribunal must observe the principles of natural justice

origin: Late Middle English (in observe (sense 3)): from Old French observer, from Latin observare to watch, from ob- towards + servare attend to, look at.
